page.title: 06ECOLOGY:ASHLEWORTH
page.content: Ashleworth and Hasfield provide grassland,farmland,mixed woodland and wetland,including 258 acres of Nature Reserve, which between them support most common trees,birds,wild flowers and insects.Foxes,badgers, and squirrels are resident and the {wetlands}provide a refuge for wintering wild fowl.The area is criss-crossed with footpaths and some of the meadows and hedgerows are very old.In the prevailing damp,warm {climate}everything grows rapidly and the trees are superb.The loss of elms,through disease twenty years ago was a catastrophe but all other species survive.The Severn{floods } and feeds willow,alder and rushes and certain spring tides bring millions of elvers from across the Atlantic. Orchards are a feature of the area.The hedgerows abound with flowers.
